transcript.content: The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian Unlimited.
Happy New Year. Welcome to the world's number one podcast. I'm Ricky Gervais. With me, Steve Merchant.
Hello there.

And Carl Pilkington. We have had an overwhelming response from emails. To be honest. We're very grateful and thank you so much. But we've had over 4000, which is just too many to get through. So we're going to have to apologise for not getting back to you. We are going to try and read them all, but we just can't reply. We do this ourselves. We're three little fellas. We haven't got an entourage and millions of people working for us. It's just us in a little room. But thank you so much. One in particular. Remember a couple of weeks ago we asked if there's any house dj's out there, maybe they could do a dance megamix with the words I could eat a knob at night. Karl just said that in conversation, talking about someone in a reality game show. I'm a celebrity. Get me out of here. Who ate a kangaroo penis and he just came out with the phrase I could eat a knob at night. Someone has risen to the challenge. We had about 70 different songs. We're going to play our favorite at the end of the show and maybe put some of the others on the website, rickyjavay's dot. So you can go there and hear great dance tracks. They're all called I could eat a knob at night.
Oh, no one's switching off now. Everyone's guaranteed they're going to stay right to the end there so they can hear, I want a bit of knob at was it, I could eat a knob at night?

It's funny, it was only a while ago. You're talking about getting quoted. Like Winston Churchill got quoted and. And ben Franklin got quoted. And now you may go down in history. I could eat a knob at night. Carl pilkington.
Carl. I could eat a knob at night. Pilkington.
Talking of all things nobula. I got a text from Carl yesterday, Steve.
A text from Carl?

Yeah, yeah. I'll just read it to you. Okay. See you. To moz for a face rub at 630, then. No bum tubes, though. So I was intrigued and I called cars and I think you've just sent me a text by mistake. What's the explanation of that? See you tomorrow for a face rub. No bum tubes, though.
Just because we may ruffle.
Why did he choose you?
He just said. He said, you know, there's things that go on in life that you need to experience.
Yeah.
He said, just. Just pop along. And I didn't say yes straight away.
What's a face rub? You mean a facial? Like a face?
Like a. Just like a posh face wash?
Like a facial where you lay down.
You just clean your face with a flower.
So you're. You're going to have a facial scrub? You're going to go lie down with another man and have your face.

Well, no, this is what I was saying to him. There's a couple of questions. I didn't just say yes straight away, I questioned it. I said, well, I'm not that happy with this. I said, look, there's nothing weird going on here, is he? I said, it's not a house, is it? It's a proper clinic. And that said, yeah, it's proper. You wear a dressing gown and that. I said, well, I'm not that.
So he's already got you in the dressing gown?

Yeah, well, I haven't agreed to that today. I've worn a little round polo neck sort of jumper, so I don't have to take it off. It's not gonna get in the way of me face. I made sure I didn't wear a shirt with a collar. I'm not taking this off. They can put the dressing gown on top of this.
Right.
If you have to do it to look smart or whatever. I'm not taking me clothes off. I don't know if it's a woman who rubs me head. I don't know if it's a bloke or...
The thing is, you get extra, don't you, for your face rub because your face goes all the way back over the top of your head down to the back of your neck.
But-but all I was-
So you've got a big face, haven't you?
All I was saying to him is, I'll have the face rub, but I don't know if- if once you're in there-
Right
They try and sell you the old, uh, the bum tube thing.
What's a bum tube? Is that euphemism? What are you talking about?
The thing where they pop a tube in and put coffee in your belly and it cleans you out and that.
An enema?
Yeah, that's- yeah.
A colonic irrigation.
Yeah, yeah.
Would you have that?
I don't- I'm not- I don't want it. I don't- I don't think-
Why not?

Just because I think I've said to you before about, you know, you don't need to be that clean inside. You know what I mean? I don't mind washing my face but what occasion do you need where you're that cleaned out? Do you know what I mean? It's always a clear tube and that. And you see all the stuff whizzing past. I don't understand why it's clear. I don't know why you've got to see what's coming out of you. Like it's, you know, like the generation game, making notes of what's whizzing past. Forget it.
Ricky laughs
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian unlimited.

Over the Christmas break, I was watching, uh, some different TV. Saw an amazing documentary. It was called 'Tribes'. This guy, and he goes and lives with different tribes around the world, these small, little indigenous people. And, uh, there was one, he went to Papua New Guinea in Indonesia, right, Karl? He lived with the Kombai tribe. All right? Now, this Papua New Guinea is an extraordinary place because it is one of the only places left on earth that hasn't been fully explored. There are parts of it that it's just blank on the map because they've never explored that. They don't know what's there. They know what's going on. So firstly, that must already freak you out. Imagine that. 21st century. They have no idea what's going on down there.
But do- do they need to know if there's nothing going on?
Well, they- they don't know what's going on. There could be stuff going on.
No, but there's no chance that they'll go, 'We haven't been over there', and someone goes and there's like an Arndale center. Nothing's going to be there, is it? So there's no-

Well, I'll tell you what is there, okay? There's these various small tribes, okay? This guy goes, he's amazing, right. Now, the thing about these is that up until the sixties and even more recently, some of these tribes are still cannibals. They're still cannibalistic, okay? Eating people from other tribes.
This is going on now?

Going on now. It's generally stopped, but it still does occasionally occur. All right? So this guy goes to live with them, right? They- they walk around, you know, obviously naked except for a little leaf just above their genitals. It's not covering the genitals, it's just above the genitals.
Do they know they could move on? Have they got a telly or have they seen a telly and gone, 'I'm not up for that?' Or are they just, are they saying-
It's not the Amish.
They haven't chosen this.
What is the difference between the Amish and these people?

Well, the Amish are group people that choose to live in that way. These people are just essentially untouched by civilisation. I mean, they do have interaction with civilisation and people do come there, but they, they still live in this very, very almost prehistoric way. They go around, they have homemade weapons, they kill pigs and hogs in the, in the undergrowth. They live in kind of tree houses.
They did buy a telly, but there was nothing on because there isn't any broadcasters.

They couldn't plug it in. They had an absolute nightmare. But there was one guy, okay? Now, he said that his brother was dying. This was a couple of years ago, right? His brother was dying. He said to his dying brother, "What happened? Why are you dying?" This guy said, "It was a bloke in another village." He goes over to the other village, he kills this other bloke. He eats him or eats bits of him. The other village gets a bit annoyed. They go, "What's going on? Why'd you kill this bloke?" They went, he went, "Sorry about that," right. They said, "Well, you need to make it up to us." He gave him them pig. They said, "A pig's not enough." They gave him five pigs.
Hang on, who are they giving these pigs to? The tribe?

To the tribe of the bloke who he killed and ate. So five pigs apparently made up for the fact that they'd killed one of them. They said, "Well, hang on, what are you gonna, what are you gonna do with this bloke's wife?"
Why were they bartering? Why didn't they just get the police in and say, what's going on?
What police?

Yeah, why didn't they call Morse? I mean, what? Yeah, what? Why did they call in Kojak? Because he'd have sorted it out, wouldn't he? Or who else could they have called in? Colombo would've sorted it out, wouldn't he?
I don't understand. What are you saying, there's two tribes?
There's a number of different tribes, aren't there, in the, I've just explained that to you. There's a number of small individual tribes in this dense Papua New Guinea forest.
With a load of pigs.

With a load of pigs. But the wife of the guy that he killed and ate, they said, "Well we don't need her now. We don't want her." So she had to come and live with the murderer of her husband. So she's living there now, you know, happy as Larry.

But could. I mean, what I mean is, right, they're miles away from anything, but it doesn't sound like the great place to live, right? Could they not move? Could one of them go, "Do you know what? I'm sick of this. I'm moving," or whatever and go to a proper city? How far away is this? These Papa people to the next, to the next.
They're like the Smurfs. They're very like the Smurfs.
But how many miles away from, like, a place with a normal life going on?

But think about this, Karl. Firstly, they don't speak the language, so they don't have any practical skills. They've got no experience of civilisation. So even if they chose to go and live in one of these cities, what can they do? How can they function? They'll spend, you know, 15 years just trying to figure out what, you know, how everything works.
Mind you, I have had the same thought about Inuits.
Right?
If you, if you live in a house made of ice and eat fish all day and then just stay in for six months - move. I really do. I mean, I don't understand why they're living there.
I think there's some bacteria that has better lives than that.
That's got to be offensive.
Why?
Okay, how about, this is the one of the weirdest things. This is one of the weirdest things, right?
Sorry!
An entire people, an entire race just dismiss.
I'm not having a go, but I'm just saying I wouldn't fancy it, is what I mean.

But they don't know of another world. How can they imagine that? They could. Oh, I'll tell you what, this is boring. I'm tired of hunting for food and eating fish from the river. I'll tell you what I'd like, a world where there's ipods and room service. I'm gonna go and move to New York. They're not thinking like that, are they, Karl? Cause they don't know about this other world.
Which is why, in a way, Carl can't offend them, because they are not listening to this podcast.
Very unlikely. Very, very unlikely.
You're not gonna care. You're not gonna get any nasty letters from Eskimos or Inuits, as they want to be called.
Now, does an Eskimo ever. Inuit, do they ever meet, like, an english person on holiday and an english person goes choppy or whatever?
Well, what do you think?

It's just that people go to, you know, Steve said before about places he's been to where people are still walking about with swords, and that people go to these places on holiday now, they like a little bit of danger. They like to see how the others live. So all I'm saying is we know they exist. The papa, people. Maybe people aren't going there. You know, it doesn't sound like the best place. You know, I can't imagine it having a tourist board or anything. Right. But would they accept me if I popped over there and, you know, with Suzanne, sort out little weekend break and that?
Where, where are we talking?
We're talking Papua New guinea.
In Papua?

Well, okay, this is, this is one of the things that they do, okay, which is a tradition you may have to do. These combine, right? They invert their penises so they push their penises back up inside their bodies like a sock.
What for?
Well, keeps it out of the way.
Of what?

Well, if you're running through the undergrowth, chasing a hog, you don't want it flapping away, you know, but, but it's also become a kind of ceremonial thing. So if you were over there, you may want to try it yourself.
You would have to try it yourself if you went there, you'd have to try it yourself.
But even cavemen had little pants on. Why haven't they?
Slow down, rewind again. You've been watching the Flintstones.
No no, it's just, you know, is.
It a leopard skin pair of pants that's actually quite gone.
But, but it's a well known fact that they wore like bear pants or whatever.
Bear pants? What do you mean bear pants? No no no. Listen, you are a qualified anthropologist. So what?
I mean, you know, whenever you see him on footage or in a museum footage.
Yeah.
Whenever you see that shake in, it's black and white as well, isn't it? Cavemen footage.
You always see him wearing a little bit of fur, little pants and that. So what I'm saying is even though, what year is it to these people in the woods?

I mean, I don't know what this conversation is anymore. He's just clutching at straws. His mind, it's like a fly, his mind, isn't it? It's just buzzing round. It's trying to find a window. And that's your mind. It is just like getting against pieces of information. But they're just bouncing off days to.
Perplex.
The Ricky Gervais show on Guardian unlimited.
You can't believe your luck, Rick. Paul 'The Party Animal' Parker has been in touch.
Ricky and Steve both laugh.
I imagine the kinda New Year party he was havin' laugh night.
Oh, I don't want to think about it because it gives me a hangover just thinking about what that dude got up to. Come on then.
Man alive- anyway. You know, he never stops, he never stops supplying us with little tidbits.
Oh, what's PP done for us now come on?
He just likes, well he just like finding little odds and ends and just sending them in and um- remember when we used to, years ago, we used to do that thing where we'd read headlines?
Yeah.
And sometimes the headline is all you need from a story.
Yeah.
And this is, this, this is what's great about this one. If you just give me a news at ten style 'Bong.'
"And now the news at ten- Bong!"
Boy waited while doctor rode unicycle.
Ricky laughs.

Yeah. Well, amazing umm. "A hospital has apologized after a six month old boy waited 2 hours for treatment, while a doctor rode up and down a ward on a unicycle. Paula Dadswell has taken her son James to a local general hospital with suspected gastroenteritis." I should point out now, James was fine- it was all... It was not a problem. But "she spotted the doctor peddling the unicycle, but was astonished when the same doctor later walked over to examine the child. Miss Dadswell said, we took one look at the doctor and said, 'you must be joking!'. His face went bright red. A spokeswoman for the hospital said, 'Of course we are sorry if distress was inadvertently caused to the mother, and we've offered her our apologies. But let's also remember that we should try and make hospital wards less intimidating places for patients, and we regularly provide diversions that are not directly related to medical care. Many parents have commented favorably on this approach and indeed about the unicycle."
What I like about that story is that, that it's the most important job in the world.
Yeah.
And the most useless. Being a doctor is saving lives. It's, it's incredible. It's so noble. Riding unicycle is the most useless thing you can do. It's- it's... that to me, is plate spinning.
Yeah.
Juggling. Yeah.
Flame eating.

Who goes into plate spinning? Is it like the father going, "Son, when you've uhh- finished university, you can take over the business." "But I want to be a doctor, Dad" "Look, the plate's nearly!-" And you're hooked and you give it a little push and you're there and you're hooked.
It's a dying art. You don't see it as often as perhaps you once did.
"But Dad, I want to be a doctor." "But the plate's nearly dropped, Son!" and aww.. unbelievable.

But what I can't make out from that story is whether the doctor was, he was, you know, he'd done the seven years medical training and then they said, you're working at this specific hospital. They whipped out the unicycle. They said, "You're need to learn that as well, before we can put you on the wards" or whether- Or whether he was practicing? Who knows if he was practicing.

Do you know what I think happened? I think the uhh- the bloke in charge of the hospital, there was two people up for the job. This fella who's brilliant, he got first from Oxford, he's amazing. And the bloke in charge's nephew.
(laughing) Yeah yeah.
And uhh, they both scored the same.
He's did an open university course.
Yeah. Yeah. And they went, "well um, you're both very good, but umm- who can ride a unicycle?
He whipped it out.
(laughing) Yeah yeah, yeah.
He went, have a go.
Yeah. And he's been practicing. Unbelievable.

But theres also the idea that if it is indeed something which the hospital is initiated in order to cheer people up, particularly kids. Umm... you know, I mean-- It just seems like a dangerous thing to be doing in a hospital, with.
All due respect, I mean first-
I think so you could pull out leads, wires...
Anything could happen.
I know. Yeah. They get you to turn your mobile phone off when you go into some wards. So "Please leave your unicycle here," surely? Do not- No unicycles beyond this point.
If, If you have a unicycle accident, Of course, great place to be.
It is a good place to be.
An ideal space to be.

But who, who rides the unicycle anyway? Do you know what really annoys me? We live near a park. It's a lovely park. And on a Saturday, for about 3 hours, there's some twat hippie with braids and dreadlocks sitting there playing one drum. How can you play one drum? He thinks, this is brilliant. This is therapy. [Drum noises] Shut the fuck up.
It's nothing that. It's not music, it's not percussion. It's not expressing anything. It's just annoying!
Yeah.

Tell you now, this would be my worst nightmare if you were to take me on an evening out. You say, "Steve, we're going tonight, right? You can't get out of it. You've got to do it. It's 2 hours. Stomp."
Ohh

Stomp, Where they put dustbin lids on their feet now. I mean, I've seen a little bit of it on the Oscars. It's all right for, you know, 30 seconds. Well done. But two hours? What is that show? What is the Stomp show?
I don't know.
I mean, Jesus Christ, after about 15 minutes, you've had enough of that, surely? I'm assuming there's not really a story.
Are they bin men?
Ricky and Steve laugh
No. I just wondered how you get into that. How you start practicing and go, you know what that sounds quite good?
Yeah, they are, they're bin men yeah.
Podcast Jingle

I was shopping with Karl before Christmas and we went around sort of Piccadilly and St James' and those really beautiful shops around there and I went in one shop, you had to ring a bell to enter. They came down and it's like a- iconoclastic sort of shop and they found things from churches and nearly all Russian 16th century pieces onwards, this beautiful carvings and paintings and statues and everything. And I was wowed by it and this bloke clearly loved his work and he was, you know, enthusing to me about these stuff, "This is from the 16th century, this is Russian, this is" and, like that, I went, "Oh, it's beautiful" and as I was looking around Karl, I heard Karl sidle up to the bloke and go, "What's the newest thing you've got here?"
Ha! Yeah, sure. That's his first thought.

I mean, that is the wrong question to ask of a man who's clearly in antiques, proud of the fact he's got 16th century iconoclastic Russian stuff to ask, "What's the newest thing you've got here?" I mean, what sort of question is that? "Oh, I don't know. Probably the doorbell," I don't know, what does he want to say, "My shirt"? What were you thinking?

I just was making chat with him because it's the sort of place that I don't think many people go in, right. Steve? When you go up to this shop, right, he's not sat in there, you have to ring a bell. He's getting on with his life upstairs. He lives upstairs, right? You ring the bell to say I want to come in your shop, he pops down, stands there watching you look around. So it's not, it's not a natural way to shop.
Sure.

Do you know what I mean? It's not nice having a bloke stood there watching you look at all this old stuff and that. So I was kind of making friendly chat. I think it's an alright question because he was saying there's loads of old stuff in there and he kept going all about the old stuff. What's there to say? What's the newest thing you've got?
And what was the newest thing?

Do you know what he said, the other question he asked him? He said, how often do you get new stuff in? And the bloke went "um, every day". And I said to him, "why did you ask that"? He said, "well, I was thinking, if you got antiques and you sell it all, what's left?" Like someone's going to sell all the antiques in the world, because they're not making, he said, because they're not making any new stuff. What does that mean? "They're not making any new stuff"?

But I know for a fact no one's ever going to go in there and buy the lot anyway. I mean, I've never seen anything like it. I'm not at any point in my life and I don't think it'll ever happen will I go, "I need some old Russian wood". Because that's-

It was brilliant! Steve, it was beautiful, it's amazing stuff. There's stuff... there's, um, these things from the 16th century of sort of like, saints and monks, and they're carved and- there's loads of it.

But there's loads of it, it's just all piled up, no one's interested. If I was him, I'd go, "do you know what? I'm into this. But no one else is." and close shop. Because seriously, it's just piled up, piles upon piles of old bits of wood with pictures on it and that.
But think of a man, just think of a man 400 years ago that carved this, that carved this, you know-
No, but nobody wants it, do they? I've never heard anyone say, you know, "oh, look, it's my birthday coming up. Tell you what I'd love."
What?

"Bit of old Russian wood". It doesn't, doesn't happen. That's what I'm saying, I've never heard anyone saying they like, I've never overheard someone saying, "you don't know where the Russian shop is, do you?" And this is in London, where the rates are high. There was this thing, right, Steve, you know, again, making chat. Loads of bits of wood with like, them old drawings on like-
It was like a panel from a church that someone had painted, and I think it was like, you know, from sort of like 1590 or something. And it was this picture of this, this saint, wasn't it?

He said 1590, could be from any time, really. So there's this one there, right, leaning up against the wall. And uh... most of them in there was that Stalin bloke, right? But there was this little fella-
Right, can I just stop you there? Lenin.

Right, alright then. So, so he was on all these bits of wood and stuff, but I saw this other little face, right? Little fella with a beard, right? So I said, "who's this bloke here?" He said, "oh, the story there, right? He said, it's this little fella who went a bit mad or something, he got mugged back in Russia." This is right, innit? This is what he was saying.
Yeah, it's just that term, I love that term in a 16th century Russian wood. Oh no, I'm being mugged.
So, so he got mugged-
He got happy slapped.

And he said, I've had enough of this, right? And he went to live in the woods, right? Made like, a little shed, stayed there. People went to visit him. And like, if you got a problem, you knock on his door and you go, "I'm sick of it". And he'll sort of say, "yeah I know what you mean, I've moved out the city and what have you", and he'd make them feel better and then they go again. Now, why has that man got a plaque?
A plaque!

If he was around now, there's no way he'd have a bit of wood with his face on it, is what I'm saying. If someone had got fed up with living in London or New York or whatever, and they go, "I'm gonna go and live in the woods". People wouldn't visit him, and he won't get a piece of wood with his face on, is what I'm saying. But this man is selling it for about, I think it was about 750 quid for this bloke's head. He's having a laugh.
It'S 400 years old and beautifully painted.
But the chances are that this is either a well known Russian folk tale, or it may even be a piece of classic Russian literature.
He's a saint. He was a saint. He was canonised.
Oh okay, well, then in which case-

But everybody was a saint years ago. That seems to be, like, thrown about, don't it? Who's a saint now in this year? Who's a saint? Name me one now. Yet this fellow lived in a woods, in a hut. "Oh, yeah, that's Saint John" or whatever. He's not a saint. He's done nothing. If anything, he sort of said, I can't be bothered with living in a city with everyone else. Everyone else has got to put up with it, but I can't put up with it, I'm going to live in the woods. Well, if you can't put up with it, you're not good enough, are you? You've got no stamina. And yet he gets a plaque, is what I'm saying. It's annoying.
Who would you like to see get a plaque in the modern world? Who deserves a plaque, in your opinion?

Probably, like nurses and that, who do a lot of bad things that I think "I couldn't do that," carrying lungs about and all that. No, but I couldn't do, do you know what I mean? That's, that's one job that, like me mam wanted me to be a doctor-
Wow!
What was she thinking?
Wow!
Oh what are her expectations like now?
Oh this particular apple didn't fall far from the tree.

Oh, when did she start giving up that dream? At what age did she start going, "Karl, you don't need to study your books anymore. Go and play with the worms in the garden." When did she sort of, like, let you off that dream?
Is it the day that she caught you with a spoon up your nose?
From the creators of The Office: Ricky Gervais and Stephen Merchant. Extras, the first series now on DVD.
Who are you?
Nobody.
What's that? Who?
Nobody.
That's right, nobody. And who am I?
It's either Starsky or Hutch, I can never remember.
You are guaranteed an Oscar if you play a mental.
I've just written a sitcom, but I wondered if you could give it to anyone you know?
Is there any nudity in it?
There could be.
Men or women?
Either. Well, just women.
I will make it so.
The painfully funny double disc. Extras on DVD now.
That was a good advert, wasn't it?
I'm just remembering some of the great jokes in that show.
Yeah, what was that for? I always forget what adverts are for. So it was for-
That was for Extras, available now on DVD.
So that. So if you've got vouchers for Christmas, you could go to a shop and buy-
Go to the shop, yeah.
Extras.
Absolutely. You could walk straight into any kind of shop, high street shop, and say, "Excuse me, have you got Extras on DVD? I've got some vouchers," and exchange them for a copy of the DVD.
And that's, that's big in England and America, isn't it? It's on HBO in America, so it's a very successful-
Well Americans, I guess, you know, the great place to buy that would be on, on, you know, say, one of the website, Amazon or one of the Internet shops-
Dot com or dot co dot UK or Play.
And search for it there.

Dot com. And I mean, if it's going the way of The Office, which is the most successful British sitcom ever, I mean, I'd invest now. I'd say "I was around at the beginning. I bought Extras on DVD the first year it came out."
Get a first edition of the DVD.
Get a first edition of the DVD.
That will become highly collectible in years to come.
And there's great extras on there, you see Sam Jackson and Kate Winslet and Ben Stiller.

Rick, there's some wonderful behind the scenes footage and there's some wonderful little documentaries about, you know, the making of the show. I mean, to me, it just makes perfect sense. It's a great way to see in the new year.
Right.
But if you are going into Amazon, you know, dot co dot UK and you're buying Extras, buy a copy of Flanimals. More Flanimals is available now.
Yeah, I don't get any money from that. So I'm not, I'm not gonna. I'm not gonna talk about that.
No. Just buy Flanimals. More Flanimals.
Well, don't keep going on about that 'cause that's not fair.
Okay. Extras.
Yeah, exactly.
Coming up, the mega dance remix of I Could Eat a Knob at Night.
Plus, of course, Rick, Monkey News.
Yeah. And you know, if you've got any, any monkey news, by the way, just, just email it in. What is it? Podcast@rickygervais.com
That's right.
But don't be asking any questions about monkeys and that, because there's too many people asking about what's going on in Monkey World and that. And I can't, I can't do it to everyone.
Well, you're gonna, you're gonna bring up what, any kind of big monkey information. Monkey News every week.
I'll have it every week but it's just that a lot of people, you know, they've got a taste for it.

Talking of Monkey News, if you want to learn more about Karl, we've just put up a, a big biography and there's some pictures that you haven't seen before of Karl Pilkington. And you can go to rickygervais.com and check out the roundness of his head and some of his stupid ideas.
But anyway, talking of emails and that, right? Nick Decker, whose emailed from Australia, right, Melbourne. He's been going on about dolphins and that, problems with dolphins.
What problems?
He's just saying when that, that wind happened.
What?
